text: hated and hounded from Burmese soil
hundreds of Ranger Muslims have now made
it to Bangladesh
they're bringing with them horror
stories of how an army crackdown on
militants became a relentless assault on
Ranger communities the Burmese army has
set many of our houses on fire some men
was shot dead and some were slaughtered
we are in deep pain we feel like jumping
into the sea they set our houses and
mosque on fire my two sons are missing
they're killing people where are we
supposed to live these rehén gia won't
be missed though many families have been
in yanma also known as Burma for
generations most people see them as
illegal immigrants who belong in
Bangladesh the Burmese army doesn't want
us to see what it's up to in northern
Rakhine State so it's keeping
journalists and international aid
workers out but that's not stopped grim
accounts emerging almost everyday of
abuses being committed against Ranger
civilians we took a close look at what
had happened in and around a ranger
community called dodges are speaking to
a hinge and using video they filmed
these people are now living in the open
after they fled soldiers who entered
their village on November the 12th
looking for armed militants with a
helicopter flying overhead the soldiers
opened fire killing men and we're told
women and children no one can tell us
exactly how many died when people felt
safe enough to return they found those
that had fallen
a day later these charred remains were
discovered we simply don't know how they
died the official version of events here
is that soldiers shot dead 25 reinjure
attackers who approached them waving
sticks and knives campaigners from Human
Rights Watch have analyzed satellite
images of dodgy Tsar and say in the week
that followed two hundred and sixty-five
houses were destroyed the government say
the rehén jur are setting fire to their
own homes it's also different from a
year ago when hopes were high and Nobel
Peace Prize winner on sand su Chi had
just won a historic election but miss su
cheese power comes not from principles
but partnership with the army so much to
the disappointment of human rights
campaigners she's refused to investigate
the alleged abuses my worry is the same
as your worry and the rest of the world
that we may be seeing something more
horrendous then we anticipate it but
unless we have a credible investigation
we will not know that will we awful
things are taking place in northern
Rakhine States whether it's a crudely
managed counterinsurgency or as some say
ethnic cleansing the continued suffering
of their hinder is beyond question
Jonah Fischer BBC News Myanmar
